en-us.learning_promise:
This unit introduces your students to Physical Science and Life Science. They'll plan and conduct investigations to gather evidence that objects can be seen only when illuminated and that vibrating materials can make sound. They'll determine the effect of placing items made of different materials in the path of a beam of light. They’ll also use tools and materials to design devices—one using light and one using sound—to solve the problem of communicating over a distance. Finally, they'll design a solution to a human problem by mimicking how animals use their external parts to survive.  

Your students will also practice their social and emotional learning, such as self-regulation, persistence, empathy, self-awareness, and mindfulness with the main characters in the lesson stories.  

Before your students begin this unit, we recommend the following to support their building and programming skills and prepare them for the challenges in this unit. 

- Access the LEGO® Education SPIKE™ [App][1] or install it on classroom devices. 


- Complete the Tutorial Activities (under the Start menu item in the LEGO Education SPIKE App. 


- Try one or more of the lessons in the [Great Adventures](https://education.lego.com/en-us/lessons/spikeessential-great-adventures) unit.


- In addition, find [professional development](https://identity.lego.com/en-US/login/?returnUrl=%2Fconnect%2Fauthorize%2Fcallback%3Fadultexperience%3Dtrue%26scope%3Dopenid%2520profile%2520email%26state%3DJfKBNEO2CQjgPV0r7GtDFY37G_6k0zdkqTrihYT6tRU.pdrmdFQQxzY.professional-development%26response_type%3Dcode%26client_id%3D25889722-61b4-4b87-a3c4-9939041aec44%26redirect_uri%3Dhttps%253A%252F%252Flogin.education.lego.com%252Fauth%252Frealms%252Flego-education%252Fbroker%252Flego-id%252Fendpoint%26nonce%3DaCnUlzakUHAHKF6_DKrUhA) support for hands-on learning, programming, and coding. (Create a free LEGO ID if you don’t have one.)



  [1]: https://education.lego.com/en-us/downloads/spike-app/software

lessons.lesson_description: Sofie thinks something is under her bed. Can you help her see it?
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Sofie thinks something is under her bed. Can you help her see it?

text.content:
Sofie thinks something is under her bed. 
Can you help her see it?

What can you see in a dark room? Why?
What can you see when the room has light? Why?

Where does the light come from?
What helps you see? Why?
Build a flashlight to help Sofie see the object under her bed.
Program your flashlight to light a dark space.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Essential Science Illumination
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="12" ishorizontal="true" displaymonitorincludedimages="11"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="HvKdHj5BtcPKTlf2io94" x="193" y="197"><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="%?Hl9|~*14J1ulOaUdD0"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="@84o-S9u^G985S5dbHl?"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">777777777</field></shadow></value><next><block type="control_wait" id="la!aneweQ7p]HK}LpdF9"><value name="DURATION"><shadow type="math_positive_number" id="@P:Y8#r?K1,Zl6bqSE|,"><field name="NUM">3</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="joM@^b]c$aUYKa)Bh-t5"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="2NTZDE.I+xhXfK9I.a_z"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">000000000</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></next></block></next></block></xml>

text.content:
Test how well your flashlight lights the dark space.
Write, draw, or say what you see.

Work with a group to test some more. 
Use everyone’s models. 
Shine many flashlights on the object.

Shine many flashlights again but point them away from the object.
Shine one flashlight and point it away from the object.

What if you have no flashlight?
What happens each time?
Great job!

teacher_support.things_you_will_need:
(one for every two students)
- LEGO® Education SPIKE™ Essential Set
- Device with the LEGO Education SPIKE App installed
- See Prepare - Materials.

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Illumination

lessons.lesson_description: Maria plays piano. She wants to make more music. Can you build her something to play on?
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Maria plays piano. She wants to make more music. Can you build her something to play on?

text.content: Maria plays piano. She wants to make more music. Can you build her something to play on?

Touch some classroom instruments as we play them. 
What did you feel?

When did they vibrate? 
What do you think makes that happen?

Work together. Plan a way to test how vibrations make sound.
Start with a drum.
Build one to help Maria play more music.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Essential Science Musical Vibrations
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="12" ishorizontal="true" displaymonitorincludedimages="11"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="RM:t,GSq{aY(R??o=Enq" x="64" y="238"><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorSetSpeed" id="ok%j#xW(QY0Vs8FJk9%M"><value name="SPEED"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_horizontal-motor-speed" id="9D`#:GH%mw/4NrCy2qTg"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_horizontal-motor-speed">100</field></shadow></value><next><block type="control_forever" id="]slHC8dI?x9B9p!]fqi*"><statement name="SUBSTACK"><block type="horizontalmotor_motorTurnClockwiseRotations" id="!-A`9cE9pUE{C.v=_)$h"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_rotation-clockwise" id="8rJ|-LAVffS^WGXf)c+2"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_rotation-clockwise">0.25</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontalmotor_motorTurnCounterClockwiseRotations" id="pvLlA,(gep%Q:zN/Gmf_"><value name="ROTATIONS"><shadow type="horizontalmotor_rotation-counter-clockwise" id="bN-`;%5q|Q7p7EUKzEn-"><field name="field_horizontalmotor_rotation-counter-clockwise">0.25</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></statement></block></next></block></next></block></xml>

text.content: Program your model. Make the drumstick hit the white plate over and over.

Now take turns testing your ideas. 
Hit the white plate with the drumstick.
Look, listen, and feel.

What happens to the white plate?
When does the drum makes sound?

Change the vibration. 
Try different sticks or changing where you hit the plate.

Try dragging the stick instead of hitting with it.
What other sounds can the drum make?

Use your model to explain;
What idea about sound did you test?

How does your drum make sound?
How did you make different sounds with your drum?

What happens to the white plate when you hear sound? 
Is it always the same?

Now test another kind of instrument. 
Use your drum testing plan or change it.

Stretch and pluck a rubber band. 
What do you hear? See? Feel?
Great job!

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Musical Vibration

lessons.lesson_description: Leo wants to make some shade on a sunny day. What materials should he use? Help him find out.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Leo wants to make some shade on a sunny day. What materials should he use? Help him find out.

text.content:
Leo wants to make some shade on a sunny day. 
What materials should he use? 
Help him find out.
What materials are items in our classroom made from?

What happens to a light beam when it strikes these materials? 
Does it pass through?
How could you test some materials to find a shade for Leo to use?

Choose some items to test. 
What do you think will happen with each one?

Build a light source to help Leo test the materials.
Work together. 
Plan a way to test how much light comes through.
Program your model so the light turns on.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Essential Transparency
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="12" ishorizontal="true" displaymonitorincludedimages="11"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="zXqZfvEPR66q6xDO0TqJ" x="229" y="260"><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="k+8E=zPsy-Ao,Mm{lVKj"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="hJ3GK6L#qthSO+jJ^nuH"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">aaaaaaaaa</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></xml>

text.content:
Now work alone. Test the materials. 
Put each type of material in front of the light beam.
How much light gets through? 
-

Group the materials. 
Use the words “all light,” “some light,” or “no light.”

Which materials let all the light through? 
Some light? No light?
Which would work best to create shade on a sunny day? Why?

Build a model of a sandbox.
Make a frame to hold a shade.

Test the materials you think will work best as shades.
What kind work best?
Great job!

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Transparency

lessons.lesson_description: Daniel lives across the street from Sofie. What can he build to send messages to her?
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Daniel lives across the street from Sofie. What can he build to send messages to her?

text.content: Daniel lives across the street from Sofie. What can he build to send messages to her?

Find someone across the room. 
Try to send a message. 
But don’t talk!

What if they’re not in the room? 
Then what could you do?
What are some ways people use light to send messages?

Discuss Daniel’s problem. 
Find some ways to use light as a code for messages.

Write them down. 
(For example, flash once = yes; flash twice = no; flash three times = I don’t know.)
Design a device that sends a message by flashing lights.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Essential Communicate with Light and Sound
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" blockversion="12" ishorizontal="true" displaymonitorincludedimages="11"><variables></variables><block type="horizontalevents_whenProgramStarts" id="BYZ-0x0,U!3bn924R?jh" x="176" y="249"><next><block type="control_forever" id="hs~?l{$KbX+wyns#%rGo"><statement name="SUBSTACK"><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="5(Q_[bMCJ~,hw_k!E0x1"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="xG-U~s9aO~F,$P9X^gv3"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">777777777</field></shadow></value><next><block type="control_wait" id="|MeI+WQ=V!^)bw^8vZh/"><value name="DURATION"><shadow type="math_positive_number" id="wO!){K.c8pR.M;U4OCRK"><field name="NUM">2</field></shadow></value><next><block type="horizontaldisplay_ledMatrix" id="I:U$mFT/H5.p#?/45u${"><value name="MATRIX"><shadow type="horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix" id="EMjLGr!f|zStL4d`I5}n"><field name="field_horizontaldisplay_horizontal-3x3-matrix">000000000</field></shadow></value><next><block type="control_wait" id="Zxx-M7qweG)lY7oj37jp"><value name="DURATION"><shadow type="math_positive_number" id="z@VyATEhVZBfQsw_([o]"><field name="NUM">2</field></shadow></value></block></next></block></next></block></next></block></statement></block></next></block></xml>

text.content:
Program your device to send messages. 
Use the light codes you planned.

Explain; 
What message code did you create?
Now plan some ways to use sound as a code for messages.

Write them down. 
(For example, clapping hands sound = happy; dog barking = would like to play.)

Design a device that makes sounds. 
Then build it.
Program it to use the sounds to send coded messages.
Great job!

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Communicate with Light and Sound

lessons.lesson_description: Daniel, Sofie, Leo, and Maria learned some lightbulbs use ideas from the way fireflies make light. Help them learn about other ideas we get from nature.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Daniel, Sofie, Leo, and Maria learned some lightbulbs use ideas from the way fireflies make light. Help them learn about other ideas we get from nature.

text.content: Daniel, Sofie, Leo, and Maria learned some lightbulbs use ideas from the way fireflies make light. Help them learn about other ideas we get from nature.

Look at some pictures. 
How do the animals use their bodies to survive? 
Can people do this?
What are some inventions that are like what animals do?

Look at more pictures. 
What animal parts do they show?

Think about the different animal parts. 
What problem could they help you solve for people?

Choose a problem to solve. 
Choose an animal part.
Draw your idea.

Show the animal body part. 
Show how it can help people.

Start a model to show your idea. 
What other materials could you use?

Test your model. 
Change it if you need to.

If you want, program your model. 
Show how it works

Explain your idea. 
Use your model. 
Use your drawing.

What problem do you want to solve? 
Why?
What animal gave you the idea?

Complete your model.
Show how it works.

What problem does it solve? 
How did the animal body part help?
Great job!

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Using Ideas from Nature

en-us.title: SPIKE Essential Science - See It! Hear It! Build It!
en-us.unit_plan_description: Help Maria, Sofie, Leo, and Daniel explore light and sound. How do they help us see, hear, and solve problems?
en-us.unit_plan_subtitle: Science - See It! Hear It! Build It!
